text:
This particular use case deals with the customer
who migrated to the cloud
to become more agile in reacting to the market demands while lowering the cost to build and operate their IT infrastructure.
The customer was into diagnostic laboratory services and the core competency was not in IT development or management.
They had a very small IT team that had developed a set of asp.net based web applications.
They found it challenging to build a new set of applications really fast to meet their market demands.
They also had issues managing the infrastructure and scaling it up as the demand was growing.
They did a lift and shift of the esp.net web application to run on EC2 instances, using custom AMI images.
In the second phase, we actually did a well architected review to identify areas for improvement
focused on cost optimization, security, performance efficiencies, reliability, and operational excellence.
This actually helped them develop a new set of applications really fast, able to test and scale things out,
and go about replacing the older stack with a new set of microservices.
In terms of the third phase, the customer wanted to actually reduce the cost. The cost were coming from twofolds.
One was from the infrastructure and the other from the database license cost.
They started using CloudFront to deliver static content more securely at a fast manner.
They started using Amplify to deliver the same content for mobile and web applications,
they started also using Security Hub for more security posture, to be able to remediate, alert, detect, and act faster for any security related issues.
AWS helps reduce the operational cost and license fee while increasing the agility of the small dev teams to quickly roll out new features
without sacrificing the quality, scale, reliability, or security of their application.
For this particular customer, it was between 12 to 14 months that was done in three phases.
The first was to do the lift and shift. The second phase was to do the well architecture review followed by the security.
The third stage was the cost reduction through migration from MS SQL Server through Aurora using more of the serverless framework.
The use case we went over is typical for most SMB customers who are web front end, a little bit of backend, and a database.
Most customers are focused on delivering business value to their end users rather than managing the underlying infrastructure
or worrying about the scaling aspects of it.
I would say reach out to AWS sales teams so we can actually help guide you with your migration and journey in the cloud.
So in terms of why this is important for SMBs,
most SMB customers actually have external facing web applications
that either handle B2B or B2C scenarios,
that need to scale and respond to varying load conditions,
handle secure communications while optimizing the cost.
AWS Cloud platform allows the customers to focus more on the applications and service delivery rather than managing the platform scaling aspects of it.
